bboxes.raw_text:
STOCKHOLM : DR.. Martin L.
King. Jr.. president of the
Southern Christian Leaders ship.
Conference and noted civil rights
leader, was named as the 1864
Nobel Peace Prize winner.


He is the twelfth recipient
from the United States to win the
award as one who has contri-
buted more to peace in the year.


Five awards are presented an
nually consisting of gold medal
and $33 900. The categories
are physics, chemistry, medi-
cine, peace and literature.


DR.. King said most of the cash
awards would be donated to civil
rights funds.

LOS ANGELES Veteran in
fielder Junior Gillian of the
Los Angeles Dodgers was hired
as the first Negro member of
its ching staff.


One of dwindling number of
Negro starts from the Robinson
era, Gillian was one of three
new coaches named to replace a
trio, headed by former major
league manager Leo Durocher.
Who asked to be relieved of his
Goa ching duties so he could
accept a major league managing
job" and the others also, were
released last week.


Although Gillian is the first
Negro to coach with the Dodgers,
he is not the first in the ma iors.
That distinction goes to assistant
coach Buck o. Neil of the Chicago
CIihc

DALLAS A crowd of 4 900
persons were turned into a
riotous mob when internal
revenue agents seized the re-
ceipts at the beginning per-
Torrance of Singer Ray Charles
and his troupe.


The first song, "Let the Good
Times Rolf had just started
when the dance was halted at
the Municipal Stadium. Nearly
20 policemen were called to the
scene S the fans threw bottles
and rushed to the ticket windows.
Damages to windows and equip
ment were estimated at 81 900.
Four persons were arrested.


Ray Charles and his group left
by a rear exit and he refused
to discuss his tax troubles.

Dance H uIfed
By Tax Men

Palmdale School Boy Scouts
Troop 3l6 liked to Kyrene on
Oct. 2. Charles Lawrence,
leader, welcomes boys l l-l8who
live in the area. Meetings are
held at the school 3l46 E. Wier
every Wednesday and Friday.
$3.50 pm.


Annual Palmdale carnival is
scheduled Oct. %, 1880 pm.


Julian School carnival will be
held Oct. 80.


DR.. Curtis o. Greenfield, prin-
ctpal Julian School attended the
Arizona Town Hall meeting held
in Grand Canyon.

LAGOS, Nigeria James Mer-
edith, Negro, who became the
first of his race to attend and
graduate from the University of
Mis- sissippi remains in this
African country awaiting fell
lowship at the University of
Ibadan.


Meredith charged he had been
waiting in Lagos for two months
and no Nigerian official had even
discussed the problem. He said
that he had not received any
written communication about the
scholarship since he had arrived.

The first showing of "The
Sickle Cell Story" a slide pre-
sentation of the strange blood
disease which affect mainly Ne
groes, will be shown Sunday, Oct.
Is, at the Phoenix Public Library
auditorium, 8 pm.


Sponsored by the Delta Beta
Omega, Alpha Kappa Alpha Soro-
rity, the program is free and open
to the public.


DR.. Clarence Laing, local
pediatrician, will appear as
the medical consultant.

LONDON = Singer Lena Horne,
At, announced she is expecting to
become a grandmother soon.


Her daughter, Gail, wife of
Sidney Lumet, white film di-
rector, told reporters they are
expecting a child in November.

The contest betWeen the tho candidates
JOT the Junior senatorial seat I'm Washing
tom for Arizona is clearly defined. The Re-
publican candidate, Paul Fonnin has bYoven
his merits here in OuY state for three terms
as an able governor.


HIS opponent can base his merits on seq
e1ul years as secretary and an 0dnai,aiS-
tyntiUe aide to our senior and venerable
Senator Hayden.


Prior to this political campaign the name
Of F0'anin aOas uOeH knOsOa in business and
CHIC affairs. Paul Fa,a,1in is no fguyehead
and he has led the State of A yizona through
head exc CutiUe post


We do not need anyone sOh0 tells us that he
knoaOs numerous political leaders in the ma
5on's capital We need a man aOho knows
the problems Of the state and realizes the
position Of his constituents.


raul F0'anin has UOiced his opinions
clearly. He urges fair and equal obboY-
tu'1itieS for all. He wants TO sOlve the
problems Of aOoteY on a sound and just basis.
He announces his deep regard for a people to
people program in increasing the United
States role in foreign affairs.


Other points included in Fanain's state
ment are me0',ingtul. He advocates health
care for the aged and q sound social SecuY-
ity system.


Fan'1in is the better choice. He knows
more people IN Arizona and since he zUiu
be representing MS--thiS is more important
than knowing scores of others Who do not
GUe here.

League Mrs. sobe Chisholm Clark associate director of the
National Urban League and Arthur j. Edmunds, executive d.
of the Pittsburgh Urban League


Nearly Negro leaders expected assemble Wash
ington December examination provisions
under the anpover bill and federal civil rights bill with
level government officials.

Members and Antioch Baptist Church. Al No. 18th
Street, gathered Sunday anniversary
of Rev. and Mrs. NJ E. Nicholson

program chairman Mrs. Watson secretary
ceremonies. Photo B. Heard
